conclusion: Ensure blocks A and B move together without slipping when force F is applied to block B.
Determine the maximum acceleration that can be imparted to block A by the frictional force.
Mass of block A is 1 kg and maximum static friction force between A and B is 1 N.
Maximum acceleration a_max for block A is 1 m/s² using f_max = m_A * a_max.
Calculate the kinetic friction force between block B and the ground.
Mass of block B is 2 kg, coefficient of kinetic friction is 0.1, and g = 10 m/s².
Normal force N is 30 N using N = (m_A + m_B) * g.
Kinetic friction force f_k is 3 N using f_k = μ_k * N.
Determine the net force required to achieve the maximum acceleration of the system.
Total mass of the system M_total is 3 kg using M_total = m_A + m_B.
Net force F_net required is 3 N using F_net = M_total * a_max.
Calculate the maximum applied force F.
Maximum applied force F is 6 N using F = F_net + f_k.
Condition for keeping A and B relatively stationary is F does not exceed 6 N.
